title: 106_hr4730
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia Recognition Act". The Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia, descendants of the original Creek Indian Nation, are recognized as political successors to the signatories of the 1832 Treaty of Washington. With over 2,500 eligible members residing in Georgia, they maintain a connection to their ancestral homeland. The Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia, with over 2,500 eligible members, declined removal under the 1832 Treaty of Washington and continues to operate as a sovereign tribe with a viable tribal government. The Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia, with over 2,500 eligible members, declined removal under the 1832 Treaty of Washington and continues its political and social existence with a viable tribal government. In 1972, the Tribe petitioned for Federal recognition but lacked critical historical information due to a lack of education and legal counsel. The Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia lacked competent legal counsel and historical information for their petition for Federal recognition, leading to its denial in 1981. Despite this, various government entities have recognized the Tribe's political leaders as a distinct governmental entity. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "member" refers to an enrolled member of the Tribe or an individual on the membership rolls. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The term "Tribe" refers to the Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia. SEC. 4. FEDERAL RECOGNITION. Federal recognition is extended to the Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia, making them eligible for federal benefits and services without the need for a reservation. The Indian Reorganization Act of 1934 is applicable to the Tribe and its members. SEC. 5 of the Act establishes a reservation for the Lower Muscogee-Creek Indian Tribe of Georgia by allowing the transfer of land to the Secretary for trust purposes. Gaming activities are prohibited on the reservation land. SEC. 6. BASE MEMBERSHIP ROLL.

The Tribe must submit a membership roll to the Secretary within 120 days of the Act's enactment, based on the Tribe's Constitution and Bill of Rights. The Secretary will publish notice of the roll in the Federal Register, and the Tribe must maintain and update it. Future membership is determined by the Tribe, requiring individuals to be lineal descendants on the base roll and maintain political relations with the Tribe. The reservation established by this Act will be under Federal and tribal jurisdiction. This Act will not affect any treaties or rights secured to tribes mentioned in the Act.
